answers.answer: Kind of a weird question but oh well.My husband and I know a couple and the husband is very tall.  I want to say he is taller than you..about 6' 6"  his wife is about 5'2" and she had a healthy pregnancy.
I don't see where that would be an issue.

I wouldn't base a decision on whether or not to have children on such an issue.The baby "MAY" have a propensity to be on the larger side, but if fetal size becomes an issue, her OB will simply advise her accordingly as to labor and delivery scenarios.Shouldn't be something to worry about in the long run.
I had a friend who was 5 foot and her husband is 6'8". They have a beautiful 2 year old and she is due in September with her second. Baby 1 was only 5lbs 11 oz when born!

My DD is living proof that that is not an issue. How big you are NOW does not affect weight of the baby. It is a combination of things, a few of which are: weight of mother at her birth, weight of father at his birth, weight gain of mother during pregnancy, development of conditions such as gestational diabetes, etc.So in answer to your question...no , size difference cannot lead to a problem pregnancy.

My Dh is 6'4 and 195 pounds, and i'm 5'4 and 110 pounds. I'm pregnanct with our first child, and so far so good. It took us about 4 month of TTC, were currently 13 weeks and all is well with the baby so far. It is possible to get pregnant, as far as having a big baby i have no idea yet.

the only time i've ever heard of a problem like that is when it is a woman of small stature and an average or "normal" man. and even then as christie said they just address that issue later when they can determine if the mother is able to vaginally deliver the baby.good luck~nanci
I'm 5'3 and my husband is 6'2 and our baby is perfectly fine lol. He waighs 185lbs and I was 115  before my son and he is perfectly normal. Hope I helped.

question: I have read that certain kinds of genetic differences between a man and woman can cause complications with pregnancies.  For example, incompatible blood types can lead to miscarriages.  But what about genetic differences in body size?If a small woman gets pregnant after having sex with a large man, is there much risk of a difficult childbirth or miscarriage?  I am 6 feet 3 inches tall and weigh 198 pounds, while my girlfriend is only 5 feet 3 inches tall and weighs 123 pounds.  If she gets pregnant, is there much chance that the fetus will be large and difficult for her to deliver, or that she will miscarry?  If so, maybe it's not a good idea for us to have kids.  If not, how big of a size difference is too risky (if there is one)?Thank you.
title: Can major size difference between man and woman lead to problem pregnancy?
